unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Coffee Shop Sales: Did Advertising Help?
question_text:
A local coffee shop decided to start advertising on the radio.
The $12\text{ weeks}$ following a lengthy advertising campaign showed sales averaging $\$5{,}785.34$ per week with a standard deviation of $\$385.23$. This compares to an average of $\$5{,}355$ per week in sales before the advertising campaign.
Assuming conditions are met, does this data give convincing evidence that the advertising campaign helped?

choices.text: No, not at any common alpha levels.
Yes, but at the alpha $10\%$ level only.
Yes, but at the alpha $5\%$ and $10\%$ levels only.
Yes, at the alpha $1\%$, $5\%$, and $10\%$ levels.
Yes, at the alpha = $1\%$ level, but not $5\%$ level.

solution:
You could perform a one-sample $T$-test using a TI-83/84 calculator and find $p = 0.00130454$.

Otherwise, by hand, use the equation below to find $t = 3.8697$, where $\bar{X} = 5785.34$, $s = 385.23$, $\mu = 5355$, and $n = 12$.

$$t = \dfrac{\bar{X} - \mu}{\frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}}$$

Look up this critical value ($t = 3.8697$) in the $t$-table distribution at $12-1 = 11$ degrees of freedom to find that the critical value $t = 3.8697$ is between is $0.001$ and $0.0025$.

Therefore, Choice 'D' is correct since our p-value is below all common alpha levels of $1\%$, $5\%$ and $10\%$.
